senses.ex: It was evident from her face that she was not happy.

Tips.title: Detecting Feelings
Tips.description: Use 'evident' to describe emotions that are easily noticed on people's faces or in their behavior.
Tips.example: His disappointment was evident when he saw the final score.

Tips.title: Beyond Sight
Tips.description: 'Evident' can also refer to things that are clear without being physically seen, like a fact or idea.
Tips.example: Her expertise on the subject was evident in her detailed answers.

Tips.title: Emotional Impact
Tips.description: When something is evident, it usually means it's strong enough to have a noticeable impact or to evoke a reaction.
Tips.example: The quality of the product was evident, impressing everyone.

senses.de: In law, something that is likely true based on the facts or proof that is available.
senses.ex: The evidence was evident enough for the judge to rule in favor of the plaintiff.

Tips.title: Legal Clarity
Tips.description: In legal contexts, 'evident' is used when the available proof makes the truth clear.
Tips.example: His guilt was evident given the overwhelming evidence.

Tips.title: Probable Truth
Tips.description: 'Evident' in law doesn't mean 'certain,' but that something is very likely true or factual.
Tips.example: The suspect's motive was evident from the surveillance tapes.

Tips.title: Technical Usage
Tips.description: This technical version of 'evident' often appears in legal documents and discussions, not casual conversation.
Tips.example: The contract made the terms of agreement evident.

Apparent.wordDefinition:
Apparent means that something seems to be true based on what we can see or deduce, but it may not necessarily be the case.

For example, it may be apparent that someone is upset, but we cannot be sure until we hear from them directly.

In simpler terms, apparent refers to something that appears to be true but may not be, while evident refers to something that is clearly true based on evidence.

Clear.wordDefinition:
Clear means that something is easy to see or understand without any confusion. For example, clear instructions mean that they are easy to follow and understand.

Evident means that something is clearly visible or noticeable, and can be used to express a fact that can easily be proven.

Both words are applicable in situations where something needs to be easily understood or seen, but clear may be more applicable in situations where something needs to be straightforward or easy to follow and evident may be more applicable in situations where something needs to be visible or easily proven.

Manifest.wordDefinition:
The words evident and manifest both mean something that is clear or obvious, but they are used slightly differently.

Manifest, on the other hand, describes something that is not just obvious or clear, but is actually tangible or physically present.

For example, "The symptoms of the disease were manifest in his appearance" means that the physical symptoms of the disease were visible and present in the person's appearance.

Evident is used for things that are clear based on evidence or observation, while manifest is used for things that are physically present and can be seen or experienced directly.

Obvious.wordDefinition:
The words evident and obvious both mean that something is easy to see or understand.

However, obvious usually refers to something that is immediately apparent, without the need for any explanation or thought.

For example, it is obvious that the sun rises in the east and sets in the west.

Obvious is applicable when something can be easily seen or understood without any further explanation, while evident is applicable when something is clear, but may require further analysis or explanation to fully comprehend.

Patent.wordDefinition:
Patent means that something has been officially registered with the government as an invention or innovation.

It refers to something that is unique and new, and has been given legal protection to prevent others from copying it. For example, if someone comes up with a new type of phone case, they might apply for a patent to protect their design from being copied.

Evident relates to something that is noticeable or easily seen, while patent refers to something that has been registered with the government as an invention.

Plain.wordDefinition:
Plain means something that is not fancy or complicated.

It is used when something is simple and straightforward, and does not have any extra or unnecessary details. For example, a plain white t-shirt is a simple and basic piece of clothing.

Evident is used when something is clear or obvious, while plain is used when something is simple and straightforward.

Tangible.wordDefinition:
Tangible means that something is real, physical, or can be touched. For example, if you can touch and feel a book or a toy, it is tangible.

Both words are used to describe something that can be perceived or understood, but evident usually refers to something that can be seen or understood with the naked eye or without needing to touch it, while tangible refers to something that can be touched or physically interacted with.

Transparent.wordDefinition:
Transparent means that something is clear and can be seen through. It refers to the quality of not being opaque or hiding something.

For example, if a glass window is transparent, you can see through it and it's not blocking your view.

Both words are used to describe something that is easy to understand or perceive, but evident is more related to clarity or obviousness while transparent is more related to visibility or translucency.
